Full paste: Mile 17.1 – House Rock Rapid (7) – The first major rapid in Marble Canyon. A large hole on the left side of the river forms at most water levels, necessitating a right run.
Name: House Rock Rapid

Full paste: Mile 20.7 – North Canyon Rapid (5) (beginning of the "Roaring 20's")
Name: North Canyon Rapid

Full paste: Mile 23.2 – 23 Mile Rapid (4) A sharp lateral on the right has flipped many a raft here.
Name: 23 Mile Rapid

Full paste: Mile 24.7 – 24.5 Mile Rapid (6) On July 8, 1949, 79-year-old Albert "Bert" Loper had a heart attack and died in this rapid while rowing his boat Grand Canyon.[2]
Name: 24.5 Mile Rapid

Full paste: Mile 25.1 – 25 Mile (Hansbrough-Richards) Rapid (6) This rapid is named for two more men of the Brown Stanton expedition, Peter Hansbrough and Henry Richards, also not wearing life jackets, who drowned at this rapid on Monday, July 15, 1889.[3]
Name: 25 Mile (Hansbrough-Richards) Rapid

Full paste: Mile 29.4 – 29 Mile Rapid (2), Silver Grotto, and Shinumo Wash Camp
Name: 29 Mile Rapid

Full paste: Mile 44.0 – President Harding Rapid (4) – The river splits around a large rock in the middle of the river.
Name: President Harding Rapid

Full paste: Mile 52.4 – Nankoweap Rapid (3)Ancestral Puebloan granaries at Nankoweap Creek (Mile 52.4)
Name: Nankoweap Rapid

Full paste: Mile 69.0 – Tanner Rapid (6), terminus of the Tanner Trail and the Tanner Graben
Name: Tanner Rapid

Full paste: Mile 69.9 – Basalt Rapid (6) This rapid has a sharp pour-over on the left at low water.
Name: Basalt Rapid

Full paste: Mile 72.9 – Unkar Rapid (6)The Colorado River near Unkar Rapid (Mile 72.9)
Name: Unkar Rapid

Full paste: Mile 73.6 – 73.6 Mile Riffle (4) This rapid has some exposed boulders on the left.
Name: 73.6 Mile Riffle

Full paste: Mile 77.1 – Hance Rapid (8) – Multiple large rocks constrict the channel and form powerful hydraulics; terminus of the Hance Trail.
Name: Hance Rapid

Full paste: Mile 79.1 – Sockdolager Rapid (7) – (Sockdolager is an archaic slang word for knockout blow.)
Name: Sockdolager Rapid

Full paste: Mile 88.3 – Bright Angel Rapid (3), Bright Angel Creek and Bright Angel Bridge, where the River Trail begins
Name: Bright Angel Rapid

Full paste: Mile 89.5 – Pipe Creek Rapid (3), where the River Trail ends and continues towards the South Rim as the Bright Angel Trail
Name: Pipe Creek Rapid

Full paste: Mile 90.8 – Horn Creek Rapid (8) – At lower water, forms very large waves and hydraulics and is one of the most difficult rapids in the canyon requiring a right to left downstream pull to miss a rock ledge on river right.
Name: Horn Creek Rapid

Full paste: Mile 93.9 – Granite Rapid (8) – One of the more difficult rapids with a strong push of hydraulics to the wall on river right.
Name: Granite Rapid

Full paste: Mile 95.5 – Hermit Rapid (8) – Perhaps the strongest hydraulics and biggest waves in the canyon; terminus of the Hermit Trail
Name: Hermit Rapid

Full paste: Mile 98.2 – Crystal Rapid (8) – [1] Several very large holes followed by a dangerous rock garden at bottom of rapids in mid channel. Formed in 1966 when a flash flood of Crystal Canyon washed debris into the river. The beginning of a series of rapids called "the gems."
Name: Crystal Rapid

Full paste: Mile 100.4 – Nixon Rock Rapid (3) – This just right of center boulder can be passed on the right or the left.
Name: Nixon Rock Rapid

Full paste: Mile 101.8 – Sapphire Rapid (7)Dory in the mouth of Shinumo Creek (Mile 109.3)
Name: Sapphire Rapid

Full paste: Mile 109.6 – 109 Mile Rapid (2) This sleeper of a rapid has sharp schist fins on river right.
Name: 109 Mile Rapid

Full paste: Mile 111.4 – Hakatai Rapid (4)Looking downstream to Bedrock Rapid (Mile 131.1)
Name: Hakatai Rapid

Full paste: Mile 129.7 – Specter Rapid (6)River boats at Deer Creek Falls (Mile 136.9)
Mile 131.1 – Bedrock Rapid (7) – The river splits around a very large rock outcropping. Going left of the rock is not recommended.
Mile 132.3 – Deubendorff Rapid (7) – Has multiple large holes and pourovers on the left and center
Mile 134.3 – Tapeats Creek – A large creek entering at river right. A popular hike up Tapeats Creek leads to Thunder River.
Mile 139.7 – Fishtail Rapid (4)The left run at Upset Rapid (Mile 150.2)
Mile 148.4 – Matkatamiba Rapid (2) Matkatamiba Canyon is a popular, short hike up a narrow, winding slot canyon with a perennial stream.
Mile 157.3 – Havasu Canyon is a beautiful turquoise-watered side canyon. Havasu Canyon Rapid (3) follows immediately downstream.
Mile 168.5 – Fern Glen Rapid (2)1950's replica dories at Havasu Canyon (Mile 157.3)
Mile 179.7 – Lava Falls Rapid (9) – Also known as Vulcan Rapid, is perhaps the most difficult, if short, run in the entire canyon. It is on the east edge of the Uinkaret volcanic field.[4]
Mile 209.2 – 209 Mile Rapid (5) This rapid has a large hole in the middle of the rapid.
Mile 219.6 – Trail Canyon (Ducky Eater) Rapid (2) Cross-river hydraulics can flip small inflatable kayaks here.

Mile 232.5 – 232 Mile (Killer Fang Falls) Rapid (4–7) – Bessie Hyde of the 1928 Disappearance of Glen and Bessie Hyde wrote in her journal up to this rapid. Her journal was located in her abandoned sweep scow below this rapid. 18 foot long raft flips at Killer Fang Falls (Mile 232.3)[5]

Mile 280.8 – Pearce Ferry Rapid (unrunnable; class VI on the International Scale of River Difficulty) This rapid was created in 2007 when the level of Lake Mead went below 1138 feet. Lake Mead was over 70 feet deep here in 2000. This rapid is formed by the Colorado River running full force into a hillside. It is a must-scout for any river runners continuing to the next take-out on Lake Mead at South Cove. It is currently considered to be unrunnable.[6]
